content.text: Chapter one included a description on what data and information is. This chapter covers saving data in an organized manner. Higher amount of data it becomes difficult to keep in our memory. On such occasions writing these data is one method. That is called manual database. The other method is to maintain data on an electronic medium. This is called an electronic database. Data can be retrieved efficiently when needed if it is saved in a database in a systematic way. Hence, database is needed to save a large amount of data and to retrieve them very efficiently. Examples: A telephone book (Manual) or a phone directory (Electronic).
Collection of organized data can be defined as a database. It is used to manage a database. It consists of objects like tables, queries, forms and reports.

items.title: More efficient in retrieving information
items.description: Required information can be found very quickly as data is properly organized in tables in a database. Example: Searching for a particular student's details.
Electronic databases can be copied very easily.

items: Smaller physical space to store data
items.description: Though more physical space is needed to maintain a manual database, a small space is sufficient to save data on an electronic medium.

items: Data analysis can be carried out efficiently
items.description: Only necessary data can be selected and processed.
The same database can be used in different application software.
Though database and software are connected, database tables can be updated without changes to application software. Therefore, data and software are independent.

content.title: Minimal data redundancy
items: If the same data is stored in several tables, this is called data redundancy. Example: Student name stored in Admission card and library membership card. If the name is changed, that name should be edited separately in all documents.
Reducing data duplication minimizes errors. Example: Storing related database in tables (Student record, Book record) reduces duplication. The name is recorded only in one table.

content.text: By minimizing data redundancy, the same data being saved in various tables can be reduced or prevented. This enables the maintenance of data consistency.

content.title: Data consistency
items: Example: Considering change of name (Firosa Lai to Firosa Rafeeq). If the same data is recorded in different tables, more time is spent to find all these places. This leads to inefficiency. In related databases, data consistency increases speed. Hence, efficiency is increased.

content.title: Increases accuracy
items: If one mistake leads to inaccurate information (e.g., correcting Firosa Lai as Mohomal Malakkar in one place only ensures high accuracy.

content.title: Increases validity
items: Properties of fields can be assigned when a database is planned. Validity can be checked at data entry stage.

content.title: Security
items: Unauthorized access can be controlled by using a password and encrypting the database. This increases security. Data encryption is translating data in such a way that unauthorized personnel cannot read it.

content.title: Primary Key
content: A column (or a combination of columns) which enables to identify a record uniquely is called a primary key.
attributes: Should not be empty (data being there is mandatory).
No duplicate values (same values do not exist).
attributes.example: Student Number is the most suitable field for the Student Table.

content.title: Composite Primary Key
content.description: The primary key which consists of two or more columns uniquely identifies a record.
examples: Student ID, Student Name (e.g., 1001 Saman Kumara, 1001 Saman Kumara).

content.title: Foreign Key
content.description: If a field (or a combination of fields) of one table can be used to uniquely identify rows of another table, these fields are called foreign keys.

examples.title: Student Table (Foreign Key)
examples.diagram: Admission No (PK of Student Table), Admission No (FK of Marks Table)

content.text: If only a row of a table is related to a row of another table, it is called a one-to-one relationship.
Two tables exist: A and B. A record in Table A is related to one row in Table B, and a row in Table B is related to one row in Table A.
The primary key of Student Table is Admission Number and it is the foreign key of Marks Table.
If each record of a table is related to several records of another table, this is called a one-to-many relationship.
One record in Student Table can be related to several records in Borrowed Books Table. A record in Student Table can be related to one or more records in Borrowed Books Table as well.
One record in Borrowed Books Table can be related to one record in Student Table. A record in Borrowed Books Table can be related to several records in Student Table.
If a record of a table is related to several records of another table and if a record of that related table is related to several records of another table, there is a many-to-many relationship.
